dialogues.speaker: PREDAWN
dialogues.text: In a Santa Clarita housing tract. It's dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes glisten in the clock's shine, patiently watching the time. BZZZZ! The ALARM SOUNDS. A hand that's been hovering over the clock drops. Silence. JAKE HOYT, a fit young man, rolls over, throws an arm over his sleeping wife --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: It's time. -- she's not there, just empty blankets. He sits up, sporting a scraggly goatee, his hair growing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LISA, his wife, in a rocking chair in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Jake is surprised. How'd she sneak off?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What are you doing up? She pulls back the blanket, she breast-feeds their infant daughter.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Mooooo. She lavishes kisses on her baby.

dialogues.speaker: BRASSO
dialogues.text: is squirted on terry cloth. A badge is rubbed against it in precise circles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake in T-shirt and jeans, studies the gleaming badge, snaps it in its case, clips it to his belt. He tosses a duffel on the counter. Searches through the police gear. Lisa taps a police baton on his shoulder. He takes it.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Wrong day to forget stuff. Everyone's saying how lucky you are. Don't screw this up. He gives her a look, shoves it in the bag.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: She go back to sleep?

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm. Ate like a pig. Jake does a final check of gun belt. Inspecting his Beretta and magazines.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I know how lucky I am. I ace this assignment. Department's wide open. Get my own division someday. You should see those guys' houses. She grabs a pack of English muffins. Jake catches his reflection in a mirror, rubs his chin. He doesn't like the way he looks. Next to the mirror is his police academy graduation photo -- Clean-cut, almost adolescent. Lisa plays with his goatee, she likes it.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Want some eggs for the road?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I gotta roll. Gotta beat the traffic. He shoves his gun belt in the duffel. Zips it shut. He grabs a pressed uniform off a chair, and his police hat, wrapped in plastic. He kisses Lisa's cheek, her neck, her lips. Heads to the door. The PHONE RINGS. Jake stops. Lisa answers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: Hello? (beat, laughs) How nice, thank you. (beat, giggles) I will, don't worry. Jake looks at her, wondering who the hell is making his wife giggle so much.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: He's right here. (to Jake) Jake. It's Alonzo. Jake reacts, steels himself and takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hoyt?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yessir?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: On your way to roll call?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yessir. I'm out the door right now.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hoyt.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yessir?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Patrol fairies go to roll call. We don't go to roll call.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: There's a coffee shop at 7th and Witmer. See you there at ten. Be in civvies. Comfortable shoes. Got a back-up gun? Something pocket-sized? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Nossir. Just my department issue service pistol.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Bring it. Cuffs, too. We're gonna be in the office all day, but who knows, maybe we'll do some business. We're an aggressive unit.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I know. That's why I signed up. I want to thank you for giving me the oppor -- -- CLICK! Alonzo hangs up. Jake too. He stands there, grabs his nervous stomach.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Feel like it's football tryouts. Wish it was tomorrow so I'd know already if I made his squad or not.

dialogues.speaker: LISA
dialogues.text: It's not tomorrow. It's today. And it's gonna work out. I know it will.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I gotta relax. Lisa looking at him. He gets an idea, snuggles up to her.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Don't have to show up until ten. She breaks the embrace -- sore breasts -- Ouch!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Soon they'll be mine again. Jake chases them with cupped hands as she retreats, giggling. Their game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old and tired, near Good Samaritan Hospital. Jake struts through the door, confidently looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DETECTIVE SERGEANT ALONZO HARRIS, in black shirt, black leather jacket. And just enough platinum and diamonds to look like somebody. He reads the paper in a booth. The gun leather-tough LAPD vet is a hands-on, blue-collar cop who can kick your ass with a look.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Jake walks over. Slides in across. Alonzo's eyes will never leave his newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir. A young waitress pours Jake coffee, offers a menu. Jake waves it away.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'm okay, ma'am. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Have some chow before we hit the office. Go ahead. It's my dollar.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: No, thank you, sir. I ate.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Fine. Don't. Alonzo turns the page. A long beat. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: It's nice here.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: May I read my paper?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir... I'll get some food. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: No. You won't. You fucked that up. Please. I'm reading. Shut up. Jake does -- Jeeez, sorry. Pours a ton of sugar in his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waitress pours refills. Alonzo reads. Jake fidgets.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sure wouldn't mind not roasting in a hot black and white all summer. Alonzo sighs, carefully folds his paper. Glares at Jake.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Tell me a story, Hoyt.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: My story?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Not your story. A story. You can't keep your mouth shut long enough to let me finish my paper. So tell me a story.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I don't think I know any stories. Alonzo waves the paper in Jake's face.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: This is a newspaper. And I know it's ninety percent bullshit but it's entertaining. That's why I read it. Because it entertains me. If you won't let me read my paper, then entertain me with your bullshit. Tell me a story.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: A real one or should I make one up? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: (sighs) Where'd you do your probation?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Van Nuys.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Right. The Valley. No cute little anecdotes about writing underage smoking cites at the shopping mall? Jake thinks. Bingo! He's got it.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: There was this D.U.I. stop.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: A D.U.I. stop. Wow. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: We were on the mid-watch.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: We? You and...?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Debbie.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Debbie? The hell's Debbie?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: My training officer. Debbie Maxwell --

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: -- Your T.O. was female?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: She white? Black?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: White.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: She dyked out or she any good? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: She's pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: (he's hooked) So you and Debbie are pullin' a mid-watch?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Right. It's a real quiet night. A yawner. We're rolling on Vanowen. I'm driving. And this Acura, just a beautiful car, comes out a side street. In excess. All over the median. So I light it up and hit the wailer. Guy drives on like I'm invisible for ten blocks before he pulls over. Plates ran clean. Debbie covers as I approach. Driver's this huge white guy. Can barely keep his eyes open. I field test and arrest and I'm belting him in our unit. Debbie's tossing his car. She calls me to the vehicle and shows me a snubbed .38 and two shotguns, all loaded and locked.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: No shit?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: No shit. She calls our supervisor and I keep searching. I find five hundred grams of meth in the dash. Turns out our D.U.I. was on bail for distribution. He was on his way to smoke his ex-partner before trial. (proudly ) We prevented a murder. Alonzo is astonished.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: «+. amazing... Jake beams -- some story, huh? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You're driving around the Valley with a fine bitch in your car for a year and the most entertaining story you got is a drunk stop? Never hit her up for some Code X in the back seat? Didn't tap it?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I have a wife.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You also have a dick. Alonzo shakes his head in disgust. Jake is crushed.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Let's go. Alonzo tosses a fifty on the table. OFF his heavy wedding band we --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake and Alonzo crossing. Alonzo sizes Jake up.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You walk and talk like a damn cop. Alonzo stops at:

dialogues.speaker: G-RIDE
dialogues.text: A narc-machine supreme. A clean, black 1978 Monte Carlo on nice rims.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Gimme that menu. Jake pulls a Chinese menu from under the wiper. Hands it to Alonzo, who folds and pockets it.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Get in. S'unlocked. Jake admires the car, climbs in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake buries his shoes in beer cans and coffee cups. Alonzo twists the key and pumps the hell out of the gas. After a beat, the ENGINE CATCHES -- VROOM!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: This isn't from the motor pool.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Don't worry. My baby puts out when she has to. Alonzo rubs the dash lovingly.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Where's the office? Back at Division? Alonzo hits the switches and the G-Ride is raised by hydraulics.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You're in it. Jake reacts. Then smiles -- This is kinda cool.

dialogues.speaker: DAY AT
dialogues.text: Alonzo SQUEALS out of the lot. They pass the formidably- stylish Metropolitan Detention Center.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Rover's in the glove box. Wanna ten-eight us?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Shitcan the sirs. I'm not your domestic violence awareness instructor. Jake takes a Motorola radio from the glove box.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What's our I.D.?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Nora fifteen.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (into Motorola) Nora fifteen, ten-eight. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Nora fifteen, ten-twenty. Jake checks the street signs -- 7th and Broadway. Before he can tell Dispatch, Alonzo snatches the Motorola as he makes a left on Broadway.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: (into rover) Nora fifteen, South on Rampart at Beverly.

dialogues.speaker: DISPATCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ten four. Alonzo tosses Jake the rover.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Bad guys are listening. Don't trust the radios. Never let anyone know where you're really at. Ever. Jake nods and smiles -- makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 7
dialogues.text: Heading north on Broadway in downtown LA. It could be San Salvador or Guatemala City. Jake is mesmerized by the crowds.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: This looks like the Third World.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: It's my world. Jake notes several men making hand signs as they pass.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: They're flashing gang signs.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: They're selling micas. Fake I.D.s. Green cards, licenses, socials. Alonzo gives Jake a fatherly look, lights a smoke. Settles in his seat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Today's a training day. Gonna show you around, give you a feel for the business. I have thirty- eight cases pending trial. I have sixty-three active investigations. There's another three hundred and fifty cases on the log I can't clear. I'm supervising five officers. That's five different personalities, five different sets of problems. You, Officer Hoyt, if you got the guts to succeed, will be number six. I don't have time to baby-sit or hold hands. You have one day to show me who you are and what you can or cannot handle. You can't hack narcotics, feel free to work a pussy desk chasing bad checks. Hear me, Officer Hoyt?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Good. Gonna show you reality. Think you can handle it?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Why you wanna be a narc?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I want to serve my community by ridding it of dangerous drugs. Alonzo gives him a look -- Don't b.s. me.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I wanna make detective. The boy is ambitious. Alonzo likes that. As they cruise down Broadway, a black and white up the street does a sudden U-turn.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Stick with me and you will. If you can unlearn the bullshit they've filled your head with. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake does. 13.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gonna be passing out baseball cards and carrying old ladies' groceries like the rest of the newfucks Washington's flooded the streets with?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'll do anything you want me to do.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Good. Roll your window down. Can't hear the street.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Stand by, because narcotics ain't about staying in the car and looking good. I bet you write great paper, Hoyt. (before Jake can answer) You do. I checked it out. Cover your area, cover your ass, but not necessarily in that order, right?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Right. The two cops from the black and white have their guns drawn on five hardcore cholos with tats on their shoulders and heads. A white cop screams at them in English, then switches to Spanish as his partner pours beer on a cholo's head.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: How's the Espanol?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Mas o menos.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Work on it. People'll be plotting the worst kind of shit behind your back.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Right. Are you going to teach me that old school, hard-charging, beat up everything that moves Rodney King shit? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: No way. I'm the new breed. I use this... (taps his head) This is my tool. The G-Ride crosses the lst Street Bridge, revealing Echo Park spread before them.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: How long you been married?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: A year.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Gotta kid, right?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (smiles) A nine-month-old girl.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I got four kids. All boys. You want a son, lemme know. I'll do your old lady up. I can't miss. Jake angers, although he knows he is being tested.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Let's not talk about my family.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: It's cool. I can respect that. I'm married. I have my queen, too. I remember what it's like to have a pretty young bride. Bet you still fuck her face-to-face.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (clenched teeth) Can we not talk about my wife? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Kick back, kid... You're so in love it's comin' out your eyes. The day you bring the old lady to the office is the day you don't go home. If you don't hide your love deep inside, maggots out here will find it and chew it up. Jake realizes Alonzo is right. Alonzo hands him a card.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: That's our Chaplain, Lieutenant Conelly. Give hima call. Invite him and his wife over for dinner. He's a good guy and no dumbshit. You and your woman need any kinda help, call him. I'm serious. Jake takes the card. Kind of smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Thanks. I will. They cruise a beat.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Who's Mr. Clean? Alonzo nails him with surprised look.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Where the hell you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: From a Valley Robbery Detective. Told me to ask you that.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: (smiles, shakes his head) Asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alonzo pulls onto a street of dense apartments. Parks along the curb.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What's here? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Transactions... See the Salvatrucha zero head on the fence, trying not to look like he's slangin'? Jake looks, sees a young, bald cholo, Neto, just hanging out.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: That's Neto. Homeboy did three years in the boyna roja. Red beret.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Batallon de accion rapida Atlacatl. (off Jake's look) El Salvadoran special forces. Punk's only seventeen and can kill with the best of them. Works for me.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Jesus. He an informant?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I got eyes everywhere. He gets to peddle reefer, make a little cash for the family. I get a heads-up when shit goes down. The barrio dot com.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: And you trust him?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Goddamn right I trust him. Sprung his mom from I.N.S. detention. Alonzo watches his mirror, perks up.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: MIRROR
dialogues.text: A new VW Beetle pulls onto the street, moving slow. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The VW passes the G-Ride. Jake glimpses three people inside, two guys in front, a girl in back. Hipster university students.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Shit's going down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The VW stops. Neto looks around, crosses to the driver's window, a drink cup in hand. Neto plucks a foil pack from the cup. Trades it for the driver's ten.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Neto walks away, disappears into some apartments.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: See the hand-to-hand?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I saw it. The VW drives off, fast. Alonzo pulls out. Follows it.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: When was your last felony stop?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Couple weeks ago.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You need practice.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: They look like college kids.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: They need a lesson. I want the Brady Bunch grabbing glass. I got front. You got back. Alonzo pulls his gun. Jake reaches for the Motorola.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Stay off the rover. Jake puts it away, pulls his gun. Alonzo stomps the gas. The G-Ride HOWLS. The VW is at the corner, about to turn!-—  18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCREEEEEECH! -- Alonzo slaloms to a stop, blocking its path. His pistol aimed through Jake's window at the DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Police! Lemme see your hands! Jake draws a bead on the girl in back.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Police officers! Your hands! The kids gawk at the two narcs for a stunned beat.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Don't look at us! Look straight ahead!

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Driver and right front passenger! Palms on the windshield!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You in the back! Palms on the side window! Look straight ahead!

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Driver! Use your left hand, put the vehicle in park. The Driver is mortified because:

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: -.. it's a stickshift...

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Shut up, dickhead! I'11 shoot your face off! Take the keys out of the ignition. Throw 'em out the window! The Driver does, quickly, as Alonzo jumps from the car, charges the Driver, shoves the gun in his face. These are just scared kids. The girl tries not to cry.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Fork it over, smartman.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: What, sir? Alonzo grabs his ear, tugs violently. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: The marijuana I just watched you purchase! The Driver hands over the foil pack.

dialogues.speaker: PASSENGER
dialogues.text: I'm very sorry, sir. I didn't know he was bringing me here.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Shut up, dumbass. You're here now! Gimme that pipe! There's an ornate pot pipe on the floor mat. The PASSENGER picks it up. Reluctantly hands it to Alonzo.

dialogues.speaker: PASSENGER
dialogues.text: My mom gave me that pipe.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: What else you got?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Cigarettes...?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Gimme those too. He gives him a squished packed of Marlboro reds. The kids realize Alonzo isn't your average cop. The girl sees Neto standing down the block like nothing is going on. She lowers her hands -- bad move.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Control your suspect, Hoyt!

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Miss! Palms on the glass! Alonzo sees her lip quiver.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Cry and I slap the eyes outta your face! Back to the Driver.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You aware this is a gang neighborhood? That gives him pause -- no kidding -- Alonzo grabs his ear again, shakes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I see you here again, I take your car. You can walk home while your girlfriend pulls a homeboy train... Hear me, reefer addict?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Thank you for your cooperation -- Safe your iron.

dialogues.speaker: ON VW
dialogues.text: Jake holsters his gun. Follows Alonzo to the G-Ride. The kids lower their hands.

dialogues.speaker: ON G-RIDE
dialogues.text: Alonzo and Jake climb in. As they drive away, the girl nails Jake with a look of revulsion. Jake reacts.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 10
dialogues.text: Alonzo laughing. Jake didn't like what happened. It shows.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Was that training? How to roust students for dime bags?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: They have no business being here. Sooner or later that little smart- ass white boy college puke is gonna get jacked. I saved his life.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Taught him a real lesson.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Sure did, buy your shit on campus. (beat) I like your moves. Someone trained you well. Jake smiles to himself. Alonzo opens the foil, sniffs -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Shitty dime. Check it out. He hands it to Jake. Who takes out a bud.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: See the small hairs? The undeveloped seeds. How it's all stems? Jake nods.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: It was picked immature. See how flat it is? Classic brick-pack Mexican. See how brittle it is? It's not bud season. It's from last year. Jake is amazed. Alonzo snatches the bud, crumbles it in the pipe, tosses aside seeds.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: To be truly effective, a narcotics detective must know and love narcotics. A good narcotics detective should have narcotics in his blood.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You going to smoke that? Alonzo smiles devilishly, offers Jake the pipe.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You are.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hell if I am.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: What? You a Mormon? A Jesus freak?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: No. I'm not losing my job.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: (re: the pipe) This is your job.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I can't do it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: This isn't some kind of test. Take a damn hit.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I became a cop to keep people from using that poison.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: (laughs ) This ain't a review board. We ain't doing rails. Just leafy green bud. Jake stands firm, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCREECH! Alonzo stops in the middle of the street, pulls his gun, jams it in Jake's ear. CARS behind them HONK.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: If I was a dealer, you'd be dead. Turn shit down on the street and the Chief hands your wife a crisply-folded flag. Jake stares stubbornly at Alonzo. Alonzo pockets the gun. Lights the lighter. And takes a huge hit, blows smoke in Jake's face.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I don't want you in my unit. Not even my division. Go back to Valley. Get the fuck out of my car. A staring contest. Jake decides to play the game.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: «+. Okay... He takes the pipe, takes an absolutely huge hit --

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Alright. That's how it's done, son. -- And is racked with a spasm of coughing.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Betrayed by your virgin lungs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 11 Al2

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jake takes another hit -- a passing driver watches -- blows the smoke in Alonzo's face. Alonzo laughs, resumes driving, takes a hit. They pass the pipe around a few times before Alonzo tosses it on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: It's cashed. INT. G-RIDE (ECHO PARK) - DAY Al2 They cruise in a strange otherworldly silence. Jake is clearly messed up, his head lolls from side to side.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Shit, you took some man-sized hits. You gonna be okay? When's the last time you smoked out?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: ... Twelfth grade...

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Left that out of your service jacket. Knew you had secrets, everyone does. Didn't know you dig dusters.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What are dusters?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You know, dusted bud. Dippers? C'mon, dipped in P.C.P. Primos. Sherm, kool, P-dog, angel dust... Didn't you smell it? Taste it?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (horrified) -+. I've never done it...

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Now you have. Remember the smell for next time. Think I'd inhale that shit? Jake is scared as hell, pale, sweaty.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Oh, no. No. No. No. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Gonna kick the shit out of Neto. Motherfucker's lacing crappy bud to get that unsuspecting return client. Hell with his mom, I'm deporting the bitch.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'm gonna get piss tested. I'm gonna get fired.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Lieutenant's got our backs. We know a week before we piss.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (panicking) Shit. How could you do this to me? Shit. Shit. Shit! Alonzo slams an elbow across Jake's throat.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Chill and ride the high. You're an adult. You chose to smoke. Live with your decisions. You cool?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'm cool.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Besides, no one put a gun to your head. Jake shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A well-tended Craftsman on a steep hill of fixer-uppers in Echo Park. The G-Ride parks out front.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Get your shit together. Alonzo and Jake cross to the door. Alonzo knocks.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: This is my Road Dog's pad. Wanna see what he thinks of you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What do I say?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You'll think of something stupid. The door opens revealing ROGER in a bathrobe, worn from years of hard living. He's happy to see Alonzo.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Hey, brother, get your ass in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger and Alonzo hug.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Did I wake you ?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: No. C'mon in. Please have a seat. Alonzo and Jake sit in big chairs. Three beepers, three cell phones on the coffee table. Roger sits, takes a bottle of whisky, three tumblers from a liquor cart. Pours booze. Jake looks around at the modest traditional furniture. The tacky porcelain figurines. Family photos on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Alright. Time to get my swerve on. Roger gives Alonzo a concerned look.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Heard you had a beef in Vegas. There's a greenlight on your ass.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I'm cool. People talk shit.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You know I got your back.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I know. Thanks. They clink glasses. Jake doesn't. He stares into the liquid, enraptured by its smoky patterns. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Jake, drink your medicine. Jake takes a sip and winces. Roger tugs Jake's goatee. Jake recoils.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Went and got yourself a daisy- fresh rookie. Roger leans back in the couch. Jake is looking around the room again. A BEEPER BEEPS. Roger checks it. Ignores it. Roger studies Jake.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Jesus, Alonzo. He's high as a motherfucker. The hell you give him? Alonzo tosses the foil pack on the table. Roger takes it, smells the PCP and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Where'd you grow up?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: North Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: What's your last name?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hoyt.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (it clicks) You play strong safety for North Hollywood High?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yessir. How'd you know?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I follow all the good players. His BEEPER BEEPS. He checks it, sighs. Dials a cell phone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (into phone) It's me. Whassup? (beat) Can't do a thing for you. Your mess. You clean it up. Don't be callin' me. He hangs up. Freshens the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: (to Jake) Here's a joke, boy. One day this man walks out of his house to go to work. He sees this snail on his porch. So he picks it up and chucks it over his roof, into the back yard. Snail bounces off a rock, cracks its shell all to shit, and lands in the grass. Snail lies there dying. A BEEPER BEEPS. Roger checks and ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: But it doesn't die. It eats some grass. Slowly heals. Grows a new shell. And after a while it can crawl again. One day the snail up and heads back to the front of the house. Finally, after a year, the little guy crawls back on the porch. Right then, the man walks out to go to work and sees this snail again. So he says to it, ‘What the fuck's your problem?' Jake stares at Roger a beat. Then starts laughing. Really laughing. Maybe too much. He wipes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That's messed up. That wasn't funny.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Then why are you cackling like a jackal?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Figure that joke out and you'll figure the streets out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Don't listen to him. There's nothing to figure out. The street's a buncha senseless bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. I got 'em figured out.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You got the streets figured out?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's all smiles and cries.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Give up. You're too high, space captain.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Hold on -- smiles and cries. I hear you.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You gotta control your smiles and cries. No one can take them away so... they're all we really have. Roger and Alonzo trade looks -- sharp kid. Alonzo pats Jake's shoulder. To Roger:

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Think this greenhorn can handle undercover? Roger scrutinizes Jake a beat. Smiles and nods: yes.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: You were just like him.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: (laughs ) Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Same silly-ass look and everything. Saving the Goddamn world.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: That lasted a week. Alonzo stands, shakes with Roger. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Brother, I gotta get back in my office. Thanks for the snort, dog. What're you up to today? Roger gestures at the phones and beepers.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Think I get out of the house? A BEEPER BEEPS. Roger shakes with Jake.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Take care, Hoyt. You're gonna do okay.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 14
dialogues.text: East on Sunset. Jake senses he passed a test. Alonzo smiling at him. Alonzo offers him a cigarette. Jake accepts.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: He liked you.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Who is he? One of your snitches?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: He's no snitch. He's a good man to know. C'mon, let's find some action in Niggertown. (off Jake's look) That's N-wordtown to you. What are you, Hoyt? You ain't pure whiteboy. You mixed?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Italian, Irish and Mexican.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: No shit? You're all dicked up. Jake looks green, tosses the cigarette out the window. Alonzo senses what's coming and SLAMS on the BRAKES, flings open Jake's door. Jake vomits. A beat of dry heaving. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Okay, well's dry, kid.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Wipe your chin. Alonzo hands Jake a handkerchief. Jakes wipes his sweaty face.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'm cool. Had to unload the groceries.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You gotta learn how to party. To handle a high. It's a necessary job skill. I'm not kidding. It's an alcohol world down here. You gotta be able to hang. To get wasted and talk shit with sketchy sociopathic dumbasses and not pass out and get your shoes stolen.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'm fine, just a little dizzy. Alonzo lights a smoke, leaning on his car, cracks a brew.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Oh, damn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful Mexican woman pushing a baby carriage. CAMERA PLAYING OVER her in luscious SLOW MOTION.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Jake stares, mouth open. Alonzo points out more beautiful Latinas gracing the sidewalks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 14 Al5

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Mmmm-mmmm. The brown woman is the fine woman. Give her ten more babies to push around. Thick and tasty. Love to get up in that... Your old lady white? Nordic cheerleader, right?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Wrong. She's Chicana. Light- skinned.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I like my meat dark. C'mon, get in the car. OMITTED Al5

dialogues.speaker: DAY B15
dialogues.text: Alonzo sees Jake has his eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: C'mon, man. Open your eyes. You'll make it worse. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Sit your ass up. Hoyt! Jake locks bleary red eyes on Alonzo, jokingly:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Who're you?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: The Goddamn zig-zag man.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Cool. I'ma cop.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You're a little bitty boot. Alonzo cracks beers for him and Jake. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: C'mon. It helps. Believe me. Gives you ballast. Jake takes one. Alonzo drives over the 6th Street bridge. Jake drops his beer, soaking his leg.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Dumbass. He leans his head on the window pillar, feeling better. Jake's eyes absorb the street's tableau of unworldly beauty gliding by. Palm trees and sunshine. Paradise and hell in one. His lids begin to drift shut. Then Jake sees a flash of movement in an alley. Suddenly alert, he paws at the door handle.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Activity on the right! Stop the car!

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Siddown, Hoyt. Everything's fine.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Stop the car!

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: C'mon, relax. You're tripping. Jake grabs the gearshift, throws it in reverse. The transmission GRINDS, TIRES SCREECH. The ENGINE STALLS. Jake is out like a shot --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- he dodges an oncoming car.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Get your ass back here!

dialogues.speaker: ON G-RIDE
dialogues.text: Alonzo pulling to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Dumb-ass kid.

dialogues.speaker: ON JAKE
dialogues.text: Running like a deer. He enters the alley. Sees a book bag on the ground -- A dumpster ahead. Jake rounds it. Fast. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A devastatingly-beautiful Latina SCHOOLGIRL is pinned against the wall by a tall CRACKHEAD. Her nose dots blood on her uniform blouse.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: The Crackhead hauls back to smack her. Jake charging.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Police officer! You're under arrest! The Crackhead punches Jake's throat. Stops him cold. Jake realizes how huge this guy is. Gulp.

dialogues.speaker: CRACKHEAD
dialogues.text: Gonna fuck you too, cop. ANOTHER CRACKHEAD dives from the shadows and tackles Jake. Both go down hard. Jake gets his arm around Crackhead #2's neck, squeezes -- the forbidden choke hold. Crackhead #1 stomps on Jake's head. Alonzo drives the G-ride into the alley. Sits in the car and enjoys the action. Jake rides out Crackhead #1's vicious kicks as Crackhead #2 convulses from hypoxia. And finally goes limp. Jake lets go, sweeps Crackhead #1's legs out from under him and hops to his feet. Crackhead #1 stands too.

dialogues.speaker: CRACKHEAD
dialogues.text: Your ass is doomed. Jake growls, snatches him up like a rag doll, spins him, slams him hard. Ina flash, Jake twists him into a pretzel, drops a knee on his neck, grinds his head into the asphalt. Clicks on the cuffs.

dialogues.speaker: CRACKHEAD
dialogues.text: We didn't do shit. Bitch is crazy and shit. Crackhead #2 coming to, starting to stand. Jake crosses to him, pins his head with his knee. Slips a pair of flexicuffs from his sock, zips them on the man's wrists. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CRACKHEAD
dialogues.text: Man, you messin' up, slick. Homegirl tradin' her ass for cookies.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (bellows in rage) Shut the fuck up, sir!

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: He casually exits the G-ride with a smile, impressed by Jake's raw skill.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Thanks for the help.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Shoulda shot ‘em. Jake crosses to the Schoolgirl.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: We're police officers. You okay? You hurt?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLGIRL
dialogues.text: (to the Crackheads) You're dead! My cousins are from Trece Flats. They're gonna blast you fools! Pinche mayates!

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Miss! Relax! Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLGIRL
dialogues.text: What? No. No, I'm not okay. Lookit my nose... My mom's gonna trip out. Alonzo gingerly examines her nose.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Honey, it's just a nosebleed. Put ice on it. Don't be walkin' around here alone. Tell your cousins to get your back. You know what those piecesa shit were gonna do. Probably got AIDS. Why aren't you in school?

dialogues.speaker: SCHOOLGIRL
dialogues.text: I was going to a ditch party. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You almost became a ditch party. Go home. Go home, now. She grabs her book bag and gets out of there.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I gotta get her statement.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Unhook 'em. We're not racking up arrests.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (shocked) Kick 'em loose?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: No. Get some shots in first.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I have a punching bag at home. I want them off the street. Alonzo squats by Crackhead #1. Searches him.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Hear that, bro? My dog, here, wants to lock you up. Been to the bootyhouse? Grabbin' ankles for the big boys?

dialogues.speaker: CRACKHEAD
dialogues.text: Suck my dick, bitch. I know people.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Kick back, who's-who. Alonzo finds rocks in one sock. Some twenties in the other. He pockets the cash and crack. Searches Crackhead #2.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Where's your horn?

dialogues.speaker: CRACKHEAD
dialogues.text: Ain't got no horn. Alonzo finds a glass pipe.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: So what's this, chief? Gonna make you eat it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Instead, Alonzo grinds it underfoot.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You, stand up. Alonzo hauls Crackhead #1 to his feet. Unlocks the cuffs, tosses them to Jake. Crackhead #2 strains against the flexicuffs.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: (to Crackhead #2) You get to keep those. Want to go to jail or go home? He steers Crackhead #1 to a wall -- cocks his fist.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Ain't the first honey y'all pinned to a wall, huh? Close your eyes. Crackhead #1 does. Alonzo knees his groin -- oof! -- He falls to the ground, whimpers in the fetal position.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Lucky I got pressing business. Next time I cut your dick off and shove it up your ass. (pats Jake's back, winks) I'll leave you three alone for some quality time. Gonna grab some beer. Alonzo gets in the car, backs out of the alley. Jake watches Crackhead #1 whimper; Crackhead #2 writhes in the gutter. It's futile to beat these men. Jake takes pity, walks away.

dialogues.speaker: CRACKHEAD
dialogues.text: Pussy-ass fool. Gonna see your ass again. Gonna fuck you up, bitch. Won't see shit coming. Creep like a ninja and crack your head open. Blow your house up. Punk-ass white boy. Now you in my world, motherfucker. Jake stops and turns around. He stoops to pick up a pink plastic change purse. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE CHANGE PURSE
dialogues.text: The Schoolgirl's bus pass and her freshman ID from Sacred Convent High School.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Jake glares at the Crackheads.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You assholes! She's fourteen!

dialogues.speaker: CRACKHEAD
dialogues.text: She all woman. Tax that ass for days. Man! Jake could kick his brains out. Somehow, he turns and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 16
dialogues.text: Jake steams. Alonzo offers a beer from a new sixer. Jake refuses. Alonzo counts and pockets the money he took. Notes Jake's stare.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Wanna book sixty bucks? Where're the suspects?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You let them go.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Get over it. You wanna go runnin' and gunnin', stay in patrol. This is Investigations. Leave the garbage for the garbage men. We're professional anglers. We reel in the big ones. Shoulda dished out some shoe leather. You'd have a big 'ol smile on your face.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I get my shits and grins booking bad guys, not beating them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A beat. 38. 16

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Man... The hell you doing running alone into an alley fulla cracked- out monkey-strong motherfuckers? Those hemorrhoids woulda killed you without mercy or hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That's why they belong in prison.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: They lost their money, their rock, got beat down and now the eses from Trece Flats are gonna smoke ‘em. Jesus, what more do you want?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Justice.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Is that not justice?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That's street justice.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: What's wrong with street justice?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Let the animals wipe themselves out, right?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: God willing. But it don't work like that. They wipe out the good folks. It's always school kids, mommies and ass-bustin' family men catching stray slugs in their noodles. You protect the flock by catching the wolves. And it takes a wolf to catch a wolf.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You protect --

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I heard you. Whatever. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: When do you lock anyone up? Seems like you're too busy keeping people out. Bad mistake. Alonzo slaps him. Glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Shut up, boot! Nothin' but shit ‘tween your ears. They build prisons cause a me! Judges have handed out fifteen thousand man years of incarceration time based on my investigations. My record speaks for itself. How many felons have you collared? Dickhead. Now that it's clear who's the boss, they drive in tense silence for a long beat. Alonzo digs in his pocket --

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Here... -- hands Jake the rocks he found. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'm not smoking crack.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Good. I'm glad to hear that. Toss 'em in the glove box. Jake does, sees several more rocks under some papers.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Comes in handy. Like a credit card. (offers Jake a beer) You earned it. C'mon. Jake refuses.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: No matter what I say, I want you to know, you did the right thing. Reminds me of when I could chase down anyone and rock their world. You're a good cop. You got fire. That was some amazing shit back there.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Thanks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: That the choke hold I saw you applying? Isn't that a big no-no, procedure-boy?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Well... I was getting my ass kicked.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You did what you had to do. Alonzo gives Jake a beer and grins at him like a proud dad.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You got a magic eye, Hoyt. You have a goddamn magic eye. Up your street I.Q. and you'll do some damage, crime fighter. They clink cans. Jake smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't know the neighborhood, stay the hell out. A Regal with four rough-looking gangsters bumps its radio through the intersection, oozing menace. Then the G-Ride rolls through the intersection.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 18
dialogues.text: The area fills Alonzo's eyes with memories.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Did my probation here. Learned a lot on these blocks. Kicked some ass. Had my ass kicked.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Back in the day.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Yeah, back in the day. Been on the job thirteen years. Today's my date of employment. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: No shit. Happy anniversary. They shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Thanks. Thirteen's an unlucky number. But I figure the seven to go cancel it out. Alonzo turns on McKinley. He reaches over, digs in the glove box. Pulls out a photograph and hands it to Jake.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTO
dialogues.text: A spit-and-polish, young cop in crisp blues, white gloves, holding his pistol at inspection arms.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Jake looks at the photo, then at Alonzo. Realizing:

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You're Mr. Clean.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I had a few misconceptions when I started out. (notes a graffited wall) Shit's going down. See that?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Buncha graffiti.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Crossing out each other's placas like that. Ghettoville and the Locotes are at war. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Alonzo rounds a corner. A driveby is under investigation. Several black and whites, crime-scene tape. A coroner's van. Flares block the street. A rookie gestures for Alonzo to stop. Alonzo badges him and drives around a bullet-riddled Cutlass with two dead gangsters spilling out the open doors. Jake gawks, Alonzo is utterly nonplussed.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Learn to read walls, not just street signs. Alonzo turns down an alley. Then pulls onto a boulevard. After a block, he pulls into a different neighborhood. Alonzo glimpses some pit bulls down a driveway. A beat later he points out a house.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: On the left. See that house? Dude named Spooky lived there. Mean old vato loco. Mexican Mafia. No one messed with Spooky. Even got respect from the cops. We'd keep an eye on his house. You like dogs?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Gotta six-year-old Rottweiler. Not too bright, but he's good with my kid.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Rotties are good dogs. Dobermans are better. Spooky raised Dobermans. On my second week of patrol, when I was not knowin' shit, we roll by Spooky's one night. I observe this old, black fool named Too Fine, all drunk, beating the shit out of this female Doberman. Beautiful dog, seven months old. Too Fine's whoopin' her with a garden hose. This dog's just crying, shaking. I grew up with Dobermans. I was pissed. I tell my T.O. 'I'm gonna take him.' And my T.O. is like: 'No, no. It's cool.' He waves to Too Fine and this motherfucker smiles and waves back and keeps hitting the dog. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thought I lost my damn mind. Tells me Spooky gave him twenty bucks to beat the shit out of it. My T.O., this good 'ol boy, looks me in the eye and says: 'Teaches ‘em to hate niggers.' Almost quit right there. Almost got out of that black and white and took the bus home. Jake looks at Alonzo.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That's fucked-up. That's one of the most whacked things I ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Just remembered that. Every time I'd seen it all, the street'd show me something even more twisted. I know you didn't see no shit like that in the Valley.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: No, I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Alonzo scans the infamous Boulevard searching for prey. Sees a gaunt DEALER on a corner, in a wheelchair. Alonzo hands Jake a twenty.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Still up twenty. Your turn. Put your hood up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What do I say?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Ad lib, boy. Use your words. He pulls over. The Dealer rolls up to Jake's side.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: What you want, homie?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Crack. Twenty dollars' worth.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Fuck you, rookie. He spins and rolls away quickly. Alonzo shoots Jake a look.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Fetch, boy. Fetch. Jake bolts from the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON DEALER wheeling away. He sees Jake, speeds up. Then suddenly darts into a wig shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dealer heads for the back. Where a door leads out to an alley. He reaches for the door handle. Jake tackles him. Gets the Dealer in a compliance hold and cuffs him. Alonzo enters the store, badges the owner.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Love doing that, huh? Jake searches the Dealer as rows of display heads stare with blind eyes.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Who you work for, shitstain?

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Can't work. I'm on disability.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Bullshit. You crackin'. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: A24 CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jake finishes searching.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: No rocks?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: No rocks.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: (laughing) Aw, dang. See? Y'all ain't got shit. The man comin' up short again. Alonzo glares.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I never come up short, fool. Open your mouth. The Dealer does. Sensing to not play with Alonzo.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Lift your tongue. He does.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: See. I ain't be gottin' shit.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Gimme a pen. Jake does. Alonzo grabs the Dealer's neck. Forces the pen in his mouth. Down his throat. He gags -- urgh! Vomits.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Shit, man! Jake is stunned. Alonzo inspects the spattered sidewalk. Sees Saran-wrapped rocks.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Lookie those.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: That's corn.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: That's Jimmy crack corn and I don't care. One, two, three, four, five... six. How'd you swallow that shit without water? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: This is bullshit! Civil rights violatin' motherfuckers. Alonzo slaps him.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Gonna act like a man or a bitch?! Got you cold. Wanna go to jail? Or go home? Gimme a name. The Dealer mulls it over.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: He in County.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Sandman. He's shot callin'.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Unhook him, Hoyt. (to Dealer) You on my team now. Be seeing you, homie. Jake unlocks the cuffs. Alonzo steps over the vomit and crack.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: And collect the evidence.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hell no.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You're learning.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 24
dialogues.text: Jake keeps looking at Alonzo, half impressed, half appalled.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You don't give a shit. That stuff doesn't fly anymore. What if that guy complains? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: To who?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Look, I like my badge. Alonzo gives a reassuring look, dials a cell phone.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Afternoon, Bob. It's Alonzo. Got your gang book? (beat) I need a res. Sandman from Mobsters... might be in custody. (beat) Okay, shoot. Alonzo jots the information on a note pad.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. That's gonna do it. Have a good one. Alonzo hangs up. Shows Jake the address with a grin.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: We go after the Sandman?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: We go after the Sandman. Jake smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near 13th and Mona Blvd. Graffiti on a wall: "MOBSTERS HOOD -- SANDMAN." The G-Ride glides INTO FRAME and OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The G-Ride parks in front of a house. Alonzo and Jake exit. Alonzo pops the trunk. Inside is a microwave box, toaster, a boom box, a TV.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Gonna open a Circuit City? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: It's unclaimed shit from property. I pass it out to informants, victims, witnesses. Help their families out. Alonzo fishes out an LAPD Windbreaker, "POLICE" across the back. Hands it to Jake.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Wear that. Intel says his wife's in the residence with two female juveniles and a possible male juvenile.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: If he's not here, why are we here? Alonzo pulls a paper out of his pocket, unfolds it.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: We gotta serve this search warrant. It's the Chinese take-out menu Jake handed him earlier.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: We can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Yes we can, supercop. Ding-ding, that's the school bell. He slams the trunk. Pulls his gun. They cross to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Get a real warrant.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I wanna get shit done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step onto the porch. Take sides by the front door.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Don't get me killed, new guy. He knocks on the security screen.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Police! Search warrant! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Silence. Alonzo knocks again. Nods at Jake.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: L.A.P.D.! Open the door. Nothing. Then:

dialogues.speaker: SANDMAN'S WIFE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kevin ain't here. He up at the Honor Ranch.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: L.A.P.D.! Please open the door or we kick it in! Ma'am?! CLICKING. The door is unlocked, opened. SANDMAN'S WIFE, an attractive black woman, stands on the other side of the security screen. Alonzo waves the menu.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Search warrant. Unlock the door and back away. She does, Alonzo snaps it open, rushes in, Jake follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake and Alonzo swinging guns around the room -- two scared toddlers in a playpen. Sandman's Wife sits on the couch.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Stand up, ma'am. He searches the couch for a weapon.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Anyone else in the house, ma'am?

dialogues.speaker: SANDMAN'S WIFE
dialogues.text: My nephew, Dimitri. He in the bedroom. The boy is ten.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Cover her. Gonna clear the house.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: You can sit. Please keep your hands on your knees. Alonzo exits through a doorway into the kitchen. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Kitchen's clear! We hear ALONZO moving through the bedrooms.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bedrooms're clear! Bringing out the kid! Alonzo marches Dimitri, 10, into the living room. The youngster trembles.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: S'okay, son, we're the good guys. Go sit on the couch with your aunt -- House is code-four. Gonna start my search. Alonzo exits. Sandman's Wife glares at Jake.

dialogues.speaker: SANDMAN'S WIFE
dialogues.text: I wanna read the warrant. Supposed to give me a copy.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (reacts) My partner has it. She looks out the window at the empty street.

dialogues.speaker: SANDMAN'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Where's your back-up?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Ma'am, please be quiet while we conduct our investigation.

dialogues.speaker: SANDMAN'S WIFE
dialogues.text: You got the gun, boss. (sotto) Crooked-ass pigs. The kids stare at Jake like an occupying soldier. He crosses to Dimitri, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Hey, little man. How's it going? Jake tries to shake. Dimitri crosses his arms, looks away. Sandman's Wife smirks. 0O.S., the SOUNDS of Alonzo tearing apart the bedrooms like a hurricane. Making a hell of a mess. Sandman's Wife stands. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Ma'am. Stay seated.

dialogues.speaker: SANDMAN'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Who you be thinkin'? Comin' in like you pay the rent.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Ma'am, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: SANDMAN'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Both y'alls stink. Drinkin' all day. Gotta get liquored up to do business? Alonzo is suddenly quiet. Jake backs to the doorway, peeks around it. Sees a dresser with a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: IN MIRROR
dialogues.text: Alonzo shoves something big down his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Siddown. Now.

dialogues.speaker: SANDMAN'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Gonna shoot me, boss? Kids, don't look. The drunk policeman gonna shoot me now. Alonzo enters, excited, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Didn't find shit. Let's go -- sorry about the inconvenience, ma'am. Thank you for your cooperation. He and Jake head for the door.

dialogues.speaker: SANDMAN'S WIFE
dialogues.text: I wanna see the warrant.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Here. He hands her the menu as they exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the block, three big gangsters buy Popsicles from an ice cream truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandman's Wife bursts out of the house, screams at Jake a Alonzo as they climb in the G-Ride.

dialogues.speaker: SANDMAN'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Y'all jackers! You ain't no damn police! Get on back here with my money! She sees the gangsters.

dialogues.speaker: SANDMAN'S WIFE
dialogues.text: Why y'all standin' there lookin' pretty?! Blast them fools! The gangsters trade looks. Start running towards --

dialogues.speaker: G-RIDE
dialogues.text: Alonzo sees the gangsters. Tries STARTING the CAR. The engine won't catch.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: C'mon, baby. Don't do me like that. The gangsters getting closer.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You bitch! Start! Jake sees a Glock pulled from a waistband.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Gun! Gun! Gun! VAROOM! Alonzo SQUEALS from the driveway. The armed gangster drops to one knee. The G-Ride tear- asses away in Glock's sights.

dialogues.speaker: POP
dialogues.text: A ROUND SHATTERS a taillight. ANOTHER pierces the trunk!--  29 30 53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- the back seat -- the front seat -- the six-pack -- and finally the dash. Jake reacting to beer spray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alonzo rounds the corner, tosses the wounded cans out the window.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Shit... Let's hit a liquor store. Jake fingers the hole in the dash.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Gun! Gun! Gun! Jake startles, Alonzo laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: First time you been shot at?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (lies) No.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was. Take the jacket off. Jake does, Alonzo takes whatever is in his jacket, wraps it in the raid jacket and sets it at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: That wasn't cool. That wasn't cool at all. Where's the Sandman? What the hell were you doing in there?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Looking for narcotics activity. Scales. Baggies. Guns. Coke. Bud. Etcetera.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Cash...?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Speak on it, son.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: She was screaming about money. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Bitch was talking shit. Trying to get us blasted by her homies. Jake looks at the raid jacket.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I dunno. I'm just a new guy. A daisy-fresh boot. You tell me what.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I don't deny my shit stinks. I will never deny that. So why do I got the best arrest and conviction record in the county. Why? ‘Cause I don't handicap myself with bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I thought that bullshit served a purpose.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You thought wrong. There's some profoundly evil people walking free on the streets right now who've killed three, four, five people. I know it, they know it, every detective on payroll knows it. Why do these turds still float around? The rules. I take down the duly deserving. I'm not locking up Mr. Nine-to-five, Mr.!Family Provider. Jake shaking his head angrily.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: C'mon, communicate. What aren't you saying? Talk to me. A beat. Then Jake fixes Alonzo with a stare.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I think... I think you're a rogue cop. Alonzo laughs his ass off. Wipes his eyes, he laughs so hard. Ahead on the freeway, a Highway Patrol cruiser is on the opposite shoulder. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Hoyt, man. Know what? You're alright. You are alright.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Whatever. I'm gonna be on the six o'clock news in an orange jumpsuit and handcuffs because of you. With the scandals and whatnot, it's open season on misconduct. They'11 nail us to the wall. (worried, repentant) God, what the hell did I just do? Alonzo holds up a finger for him to stop and pulls over on the shoulder opposite the cruiser. A highway patrolman helps a distressed female motorist change a tire.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You're in a privileged position to learn a thing or two if you can keep your mouth shut and your eyes open. If you're serious about doing good in the real world, this is the place to learn how. Gun! Gun! Gun! If this shit shakes you up, go back to Division and cry to the Watch Commander. He'll find you a nice job lighting flares and measuring wrecks. Decide now if you want to be a wolf or a sheep. If you want on my squad, I'll sign your card. Alonzo stops the car. Alonzo puts his foot on the dash, reveals his unit's tattoo on his ankle. Jake reacts.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Get your ink. (re: the patrolman) Or get out and give him a hand. Alonzo reaches over and opens Jake's door. Jake looks around, looks at the tattoo. Forget it, he's out. Jake exits the car. Jake stands on the shoulder, squints at the patrolman fighting lugnuts. Jake knows what he wants to do. He gets back in the G-ride. Slams the door and nails Alonzo with a steely look of resolve.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'm in. Alonzo holds out his hand. Jake shakes, serious. Solemn. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Welcome to Narcotics, Officer Hoyt.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'm going to do my best.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You do and you'll run the unit some day. (a beat) You hungry? Let's code seven. Alonzo SCREECHES out of there.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 31
dialogues.text: thru 37

dialogues.speaker: DAY 38
dialogues.text: Jake nervously glances around one of the toughest parts of the city. A strong point adorned with wrought iron and concertina wire. Alonzo looks around cautiously, puts his gun in his lap, wary.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What are you doing? We'll be killed coming in here.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Oh, you've heard about this neck of the woods?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: This is the Jungle. They said never come in here with anything less than a platoon.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 39
dialogues.text: Alonzo enters a cul-de-sac of run-down houses and apartments. Formidable fences line the entire block. A fortress.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: This is the heart right here. The headquarters. A lot of murder investigations lead here. One way in, no way out. Strictly heavy hitters. Damus don't play. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jake is really uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I thought we were going to eat. A little kid runs out of the corner house. He eyes Alonzo, then hops on his bike and rides OUT OF VIEW into the cul-de-sac. A beat. The little kid returns. Waves Alonzo into the cul-de-sac. Alonzo turns onto the dangerous dead-end, driving around a poorly-parked van.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Lots of eyes on us right now. Never come up in here without me. For your safety. I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Okay. Why do you have a golden pass? The little kid gives Jake an unsettling maddog stare.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Because I'm square with 'em. But they know if the line is crossed, I'm leading the platoon in here. Two solid, early teen gangsters lean against a fence. One claps sharply. Alonzo gestures for Jake to look up through the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen pigeons dive from the sky, right at the G-ride.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO SCENE
dialogues.text: Jake reacts. The gangster claps his hands again and the pigeons pull out of their dive and arc back into the sky. The gangster smiles at Alonzo.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What the hell was that?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: They're flipping pigeons to let folks know I'm here. Jake looking at Alonzo, lost. Alonzo grins. At the far end of a driveway, more gangsters work out and drink. One of them is benching over 300 pounds. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Alonzo parks at the end of the cul-de-sac. Jake and Alonzo get out. Cross to a gate where two more GANGSTERS kick it. They look at Jake.

dialogues.speaker: GANGSTER
dialogues.text: ‘Sup, Lonz. Thanks for helping my cousin.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I got your back, dog. (re: Jake) He's my people. Alonzo pushes open the gate. The gangsters regard him coldly as he passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind Alonzo's back, the gangsters' disposition becomes disdain.

dialogues.speaker: GANGSTER
dialogues.text: Sick'a that pig actin' like king- shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids play in the bare dirt yard. A huge pit bull is chain to a tree.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (re: the gangsters) And those guys?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Punk ass fools. I got all these busters under my thumb. An old woman sweeps her doorstep and glares at Jake.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Buenas tardes, Dona Lucila. The old woman smiles, nods. Jake and Alonzo cross to some stairs, climb the steps. A 15-year-old girl exits with a laundry basket. Alonzo leers.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Gonna throw her dad in jail. Raise her up myself. Like veal. Jake reacts, unsure if Alonzo is joking.  59. 41 EXT. SARA'S APARTMENT - DAY 4l Alonzo knocks on a door.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What's here?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: A loving touch.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Quien...?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Policia, senorita. The door opens, there stands SARA, a ravishing Salvadoran in a housedress. She hugs Alonzo, plants a big kiss on him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 41 CONTINUED: 4l

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Hi, papi. She notices Jake and backs off.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: He's just my new guy. She holds out her hand. They shake.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Hi. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Good, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Come in, come in. Welcome to my house. Alonzo enters, Jake follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room is filled with Salvadoran kitsch. It's bright, airy, a refuge. A 2-year-old boy on the couch watches cartoons. Alonzo motions for Jake to sit.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You had a rough morning. Relax and let her hook you up. He disappears into the bedroom. Sara hands Jake the remote.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: Here. Take this. I have cable. You watch what you want. This is your house. Don't be shy. She crosses to the kitchen. Sounds of POTS, DISHES. Jake is about to change the channel. The kid gives hima look. He puts away the remote. Sara returns with a massive tray of food, chicken stew, beans, rice, salad, tortillas, the works. She sets the mouth-watering spread before Jake.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: This is El Salvador food. I hope you like it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Thank you. This is great. I'm starving. She hangs a beat, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: SARA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I have to... Jake knows. She runs off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake dozes, his plate wiped clean, an arm around the little kid, still watching cartoons. Alonzo enters, invigorated, he kicks Jake's foot.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Let's go. We're rollin'. Gotta meeting in fifteen. Jake stirs, stretches. Stands. Alonzo shows him the door.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Go to the car.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I'd like to thank her for the food. It was great.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I'll tell her, don't worry. Jake tussles the kid's hair.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: See you later, little man. Jake exits. Alonzo picks up his son. Hugs him tight.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: (subtitled) Hey. Como esta, mijo? Te portas bien? Esta creciendo, papasito. (How are you, son? You're getting big.) Sara watches from the bedroom doorway. Seeing Alonzo like this rips her apart.

dialogues.speaker: DAY 44
dialogues.text: Heading east on 6th Street. The buildings of downtown loom ahead. The noon sun high and bright.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: What about your queen?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Sara's my princess.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: I like her. She's a really cool lady.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: So are her two sisters. They look damn good and they party. How'd you like to be in the middle of a bitch sandwich? Come to Vegas with us.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: No, thanks. I get mine at home.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You're missing out. I should know.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Her kid looks just like you. He's number five?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Number six.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Six kids. That's all? Or you holding royal court in a few more houses?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: I'm only aware of six.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: It's easy to make a baby --

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: -- and hard to take care of one. Fuck you, okay? No one's going hungry. Everyone gets plenty of what they need: toys, shoes, clothes.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Love? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Alonzo shoots a look at Jake.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Let's not talk about my family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The G-Ride pulls up to the downtown L.A. landmark. Alonzo's CELL RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Get out. Jake does. Alonzo talks on his cell a heated beat. Jake overhears:

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: You'll get the damn money. Alonzo hangs up, exits the car uncharacteristically shake He and Jake cross to the entrance. Alonzo slips an old man polishing shoes a twenty. Alonzo, the raid jacket tucked underarm, hands Jake some eyedrops.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Use it. Jake does. Alonzo opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Who's here?

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Don't speak unless spoken to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leather booths and big, padded chairs. It's empty. Save for a corner table. Three scary 40ish bruisers in immaculate suits, DOUG, STAN, and LOU, share a top-notch cabernet. Doug and Stan see Alonzo, react like they've seen a ghost. Lou turns, sees Alonzo. And quickly stands. It's tense. Like there could be a gunfight. Jake's hand creeps to his gun. Alonzo and Lou converge, trading serious questions and answers with their eyes. Jake watches Stan and Doug. They watch him. Alonzo and Lou grab hands grimly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: (softly) I don't know why I'm meeting you. I don't talk to dead men.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: (smiles, winks) Ain't dead yet, you prick. They shake vigorously, smile big. Everyone relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: LOU
dialogues.text: Who the hell is Ricky Rookie? Alonzo grabs Jake's shoulder, pulls him into the huddle. Jake notes none wear shoes.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: This is Jake Hoyt, first day in my squad. Jake shakes Lou's hand. Sees an LAPD Captain's badge on his belt. Jake realizes these guys are police administrators.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: Jake, this is Lou Jacobs. You ever have to talk to a fed, talk to this man first. He'll get your back.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
dialogues.text: This is Stan Gursky, runs the D.A.'s shooting team. Think about him before you pull a trigger, okay? Stan will rock your world if you make a bad call.

dialogues.speaker: JAKE
dialogues.text: (shaking with Stan) Pleased to meet you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALONZO
